title: Performance Status
summary: A comprehensive guide to performance status assessment in oncology practice, including tools, clinical implications, and future directions.
author: OncoVISTA Team

content.text: Performance Status
Topic 9: Key Takeaways
Expanded and clinically contextualized for practice, research, and education
1. Definition and Purpose

Performance status (PS) is a clinician-assessed summary measure of a patient's ability to perform everyday activities. It is one of the most consistently used clinical predictors in oncology. PS reflects underlying physiologic reserve, and thus directly impacts decisions regarding:

items: Treatment intensity
Clinical trial eligibility
Prognosis and survival
Referral to palliative or supportive care

content.text: PS should be interpreted dynamically, with reassessment at every clinical milestone.
2. Core Performance Status Tools Overview

rows: Simple, rapid; standard for trials and systemic therapy decisions
Higher resolution; more sensitive to functional trajectory
Behavior- and play-based; caregiver input essential

content.text: Use ECOG or KPS depending on context; for pediatrics, always apply Lansky.
3. Beyond Standard PS: Geriatric and Frailty Tools
ECOG/KPS alone often miss hidden vulnerabilities in older patients. Supplement with:

items: CGA (Comprehensive Geriatric Assessment): Full multidomain evaluation
G8: 8-item screening for early frailty detection
CFS: Rapid bedside frailty stratification (1–9 scale)
VES-13: 13-item functional vulnerability tool
Balducci Classification: Clinically segments elderly into fit, vulnerable, and frail

content.text: These tools are predictive of toxicity, hospitalization, and mortality, especially when ECOG is 1–2.
4. Treatment Planning Based on PS

rows: Dose-reduced or monotherapy; assess for CGA
Palliative care focus; avoid high-toxicity regimens

content.text: Poor PS is a key signal to re-evaluate treatment goals and prioritize quality of life.
5. Clinical Trial Implications
PS has historically been used to standardize safety in trials, but this may exclude patients most representative of real-world practice.

items: Most Phase II/III trials require ECOG ≤1
Elderly and ECOG ≥2 patients are underrepresented
Innovative trials now use:
PS stratification arms
CGA-guided eligibility
Inclusion of real-world data (RWD) cohorts

content.text: Regulatory trend: Increasing pressure to balance safety with inclusivity and relevance.
6. Pediatric and Elderly Considerations
In children, PS must be contextualized by:

items: Developmental stage
Play and school function
Use Lansky Scale (0–100)

content.text: In older adults:

items: Combine ECOG with frailty measures
Assess ADLs, cognition, nutrition, caregiver support

content.text: PS interpretation must go beyond the score and into the life context of the patient.
7. When to Reassess PS
Performance status is not static. It should be re-evaluated:

items: At diagnosis
Before starting a new treatment line
After hospitalization or treatment toxicity
At any point of clinical decline or new symptoms
During goals-of-care or hospice discussions

content.text: Always document changes and their clinical impact.
8. Future Directions
Emerging technologies are modernizing PS:

items: Wearables: Step count, mobility, activity duration
Mobile health apps: Daily fatigue, mood, pain input
AI models: Infer PS from EMR notes, labs, imaging
Remote CGA: Digital geriatric assessments via telemedicine

content.text: These tools promise to make PS more objective, continuous, and patient-centered.
9. Ethical Use of PS
PS must never be used punitively. Instead, it should:

items: Guide realistic conversations about treatment options
Help patients and caregivers understand risks vs benefit
Ensure decisions are goal-aligned and ethically sound
Avoid systemic biases in interpreting PS, especially in underserved populations

content.text: Quote for framing: "Your strength and daily function give us a sense of what treatments will help — and which might cause harm. Let's decide what fits best with your goals."
10. Final Summary
Performance status remains a foundational pillar of oncology care. Used wisely, it can:

items: Clarify who benefits from therapy
Support personalized, age-appropriate care
Inform palliative or hospice transitions
Strengthen multidisciplinary planning and communication

content.text: Key principles to remember:

items: Select the right tool for age, setting, and decision
Supplement ECOG/KPS with geriatric and psychosocial insights
Reassess frequently and document clearly
Embrace technology to enhance, not replace, clinical judgment
